name: Magnolia Bark
summary: Magnolia bark, derived from Magnolia officinalis, has been used in traditional Chinese medicine for anxiety, stress, and sleep. Its active compounds, honokiol and magnolol, exert GABAergic, anti-inflammatory, and neuroprotective effects.
description: Magnolia bark extract has a long history of use in traditional Chinese and Japanese medicine as an anxiolytic, sedative, and digestive aid. Modern research highlights honokiol and magnolol, its primary bioactive compounds, for their potential to modulate GABA-A receptors, reduce cortisol, and support neuroprotection. It is being studied for anxiety, depression, insomnia, neurodegenerative disorders, and metabolic conditions, though robust human clinical trials remain limited.

metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for psychiatric indications)

contraindications: Concurrent CNS depressant use (risk of additive sedation)
monitoring_required: Monitor for excessive sedation if combined with other calming agents

sections.text: Honokiol and magnolol modulate GABA-A receptors, enhancing inhibitory neurotransmission and reducing excitability. They also reduce cortisol and inflammatory markers, and demonstrate neuroprotective and antioxidant effects in preclinical studies.

adult.range: 200–800 mg depending on preparation and combination (e.g., Relora blend)

sections.text: May reduce acute stress within hours; sustained benefits for anxiety and sleep typically occur after 2–4 weeks.

serious: Excessive sedation (rare, typically in high doses or with co-sedatives)

other: Avoid concurrent use with strong sedatives, alcohol, or hypnotics.
Not recommended during pregnancy due to insufficient safety data.

items: Sedation level when combined with other calming agents

sections.geriatrics: Generally safe but may increase sedation risk

sections.text: No formal tapering required; may discontinue abruptly. Gradual reduction recommended if taken long-term for sleep to avoid rebound insomnia.

items: Often combined with Phellodendron amurense (Relora) for synergistic anxiolytic effects.
Honokiol has shown preclinical promise in reducing neuroinflammation and promoting neurogenesis.
Human trials remain limited; most data from animal studies or small pilot studies.

items.label: Kuribara H et al. Anxiolytic effects of honokiol. Neuropharmacology. 1998.
